docs.snippet: Fernanda Montenegro's rough-hewn integrity is the one quality that ennobles this confused mixture of cat-and-mouse thriller and sentimental old folks' love story....
docs.lead_paragraph: An actress with Bette Davis eyes may never win the Miss Universe title. But if those eyes belong to significant talent, their magnetic field can attract Oscar nominations and film festival awards beyond the grasp of any shrink-wrapped beauty contestant. The wonderful Brazilian actress Fernanda Montenegro, familiar to us from ''Central Station,'' has only to widen her soulful brown eyes to suggest a sorrowful kindhearted South American answer to Giulietta Masina. Ms. Montenegro's rough-hewn integrity is the one quality that ennobles ''The Other Side of the Street,'' an otherwise confused mixture of cat-and-mouse thriller and sentimental old folks' love story that is well below the level of ''Central Station.'' The movie's scenario suggests ''Rear Window'' as it might have been rejiggered for another bright-eyed Davis spinoff, Angela Lansbury playing everyone's favorite snoop, Jessica Fletcher.
docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews movie The Other Side of the Street, directed by Marcos Bernstein and starring Fernanda Montenegro and Raul Cortez; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Despite worries that the Academy Awards will have fewer viwers than usual, most marketers are standing by their decisions to spend a record amount for each 30-second spot....
docs.lead_paragraph: AS sponsors prepare for the 77th annual Academy Awards, to be broadcast on Sunday by ABC, they wonder whether these facts may add up to fewer viewers than usual: The show has an untested first-time host, the comedian Chris Rock.
docs.abstract: Sponsors for Academy Awards wonder whether some factors may add up to fewer viewers than usual: show has untested first-time host, comedian Chris Rock, five nominees for best picture combined have sold fewer tickets than 2003 winner, The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, and of two most-talked-about films of last year, one, Fahrenheit 9/11, received no nominations, and other, The Passion of the Christ, received only three, in technical categories; many major marketers buying commercial time during Oscars say they stand by their decisions to spend record average of $1.6 million for each 30-second spot; some ad executives comments; photos (M)

docs.snippet: The Czech Republic's nominee for the best foreign film Oscar skips from buoyant satire to domestic melodrama, leaving behind a curious mix of emotions....
docs.lead_paragraph: Jan Hrebejk's ''Up and Down,'' the Czech Republic's nominee for the best foreign film Oscar, follows the mood swings suggested by its title. Tracing the generally unhappy doings of a dozen or so loosely connected people in contemporary Prague, it skips from buoyant satire to domestic melodrama, leaving behind a curious mix of emotions. It is not often you see a movie so bracingly pessimistic about the human condition that dispenses its dose of bad news with such good cheer.
docs.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie Up and Down, directed by Jan Hrebejk and starring Natasa Burger and Jiri Machacek; photo (M)

headline.main: Czechs So Divided That Bad News Is Rarely All Bad

docs.snippet: United States authorities in Texas reported that they had detained a suspected member of the feared Mara Salvatrucha street gang who is believed to have led an attack on a public bus in Honduras in December that left 28 people dead, including six ...
docs.lead_paragraph: United States authorities in Texas reported that they had detained a suspected member of the feared Mara Salvatrucha street gang who is believed to have led an attack on a public bus in Honduras in December that left 28 people dead, including six children. The United States Customs and Border Protection officials said the suspect, Ebner Aníbal Rivera-Paz, had been detained in Falfurrias, Tex., in connection with a traffic violation. Óscar Álvarez, the Honduran Security Minister, said the government would seek Mr. Rivera's extradition. Ginger Thompson (NYT)
docs.abstract: Ebner Anibal Rivera-Paz is detained by United States Customs and Border Protection officials for suspicion of involvement in December 2004 attack on Honduras public bus; Honduran Security Min Oscar Alvarez says government will seek extradition (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: U.S. Arrests Massacre Suspect

docs.snippet: The ratings decline for awards shows has been attributed to a number of factors, from a dearth of big stars in the presentations to the sheer number of shows....
docs.lead_paragraph: More than 16 million people saw Jamie Foxx come close to breaking down at the Golden Globe Awards last month. Mr. Foxx, accepting the award for best actor in a film (as Ray Charles in the director Taylor Hackford's ''Ray''), tried to say that he believed his grandmother was looking down on him from heaven but had to stop to compose himself. The people who missed that speech included about 10 million who had watched the Golden Globes in 2004 but didn't bother tuning in this year. In the world of awards-show ratings, this is hardly an isolated case. The Grammys, broadcast this month on CBS, attracted roughly 19 million viewers, a 28 percent decline from last year. Even the Oscars have been steadily dropping in viewership. The 1998 telecast, when ''Titanic'' won 11 awards, was the last big success, with more than 87 million viewers in the United States. Last year about 43.5 million watched. This Sunday night, when the 77th annual Academy Awards are shown on ABC, the numbers are not expected to soar.
docs.abstract: There has been sharp decline in viewership, and therefore ratings, of recent awards ceremonies, including Golden Globes and Grammys and Academy Awards, which will air on February 27; factors contributing to decline include dearth of big stars in presentations and sheer number of awards shows; graph (M)

headline.main: The Loser: The Ratings For Awards

docs.snippet: Lauren Bacall has chosen to write and speak about all that has happened in her life with a candor that one has long stopped associating with the well known....
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the 1970's Lauren Bacall wrote what was to become the first volume of her autobiography, ''By Myself,'' a book that chronicled her life as an only child, her discovery by Diana Vreeland, her rise in Hollywood, her marriages, one blissful and one turbulent, to Humphrey Bogart and Jason Robards. ''Has it really been 27 years?'' Ms. Bacall asks in the first line of the 179-page sequel, ''And Then Some,'' to be published next week by HarperCollins (along with a rerelease of the 1978 ''By Myself'' in the same volume). ''I can't believe it. Time flies even when you're not having fun.''
docs.abstract: At Home With interview with Lauren Bacall, now 80, in her memento-filled apartment in New York; her new book And Then Some is sequel to 1978 memoir By Myself; photos (M)
docs.section_name: Movies; Home and Garden; Style; Books

docs.snippet: Oscar season brings out the sparkle in some Los Angeles stores. This week TableArt, a recently opened boutique that specializes in stylish tableware, is featuring an Oscar-theme arrangement of two new lines of china from the German manufacturer Di...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar season brings out the sparkle in some Los Angeles stores. This week TableArt, a recently opened boutique that specializes in stylish tableware, is featuring an Oscar-theme arrangement of two new lines of china from the German manufacturer Dibbern: Golden Pearls, by the designer Bodo Sperlein, and Pure Gold (both below, $261 for a five-piece setting). ''We thought setting tables in Golden Pearls is the perfect complement to the pursuit of Oscar gold,'' said Walter Lowry, an owner of the store, who opened TableArt at the end of last year with his business partner, Steve Flynn. TableArt is at 7977 Melrose Avenue; (323)653-8278.
docs.abstract: TableArt boutique in Los Angeles features Oscar-themed china arrangement by German manufacturer Dibbern; photo (Currents: Los Angeles) (S)

headline.main: If the Stars Can Wear Pearls, Then Why Can't the China?

docs.snippet: Attention to the tactile extends to the home of Colleen Atwood, who is among Hollywood's leading costume designers....
docs.lead_paragraph: COLLEEN ATWOOD has a lifelong belief in the power of clothing. As the class contrarian of the grammar school she attended in a small farming town in eastern Washington, she wore a white blazer with a preppy emblem on the pocket and white buck shoes. ''I always loved clothes,'' she said, ''just not clothes that were appropriate to the place I grew up in.'' Today Ms. Atwood, who is in her mid-50's, is among Hollywood's leading costume designers, known for her mastery of garb for every imaginable form, from westerns to period epics to science fiction fantasies. Her work has earned five Academy Award nominations, and she won an Oscar two years ago for the vampish spangled dance outfits worn by Renée Zellweger and Catherine Zeta-Jones and the double-breasted suits worn by Richard Gere in ''Chicago.'' This year she is nominated for the macabre and fantastical attire in ''Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events.''
docs.abstract: Hollywood costume designer Colleen Atwood, known for mastery of garb for every imaginable form, has sunny modern home in Pacific Palisades that is filled with tactile sensations of swaths of fabric; photos (M)

headline.main: A Costume Drama In Modern Dress

docs.snippet: Bound for Glory      John Fogerty, below, Steve Cropper, Isaac Hayes and David Porter, Richard and Robert Sherman and Bill Withers are to be inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in ceremonies on June 9 in the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Manhat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Bound for Glory John Fogerty, below, Steve Cropper, Isaac Hayes and David Porter, Richard and Robert Sherman and Bill Withers are to be inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in ceremonies on June 9 in the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Manhattan, Reuters reported. Leading Creedence Clearwater Revival, Mr. Fogerty wrote classics including ''Proud Mary,'' ''Bad Moon Rising'' and ''Who'll Stop the Rain''; after going solo, he delivered hits like ''Old Man Down the Road'' and ''Centerfield.'' Mr. Cropper, a founder of Booker T and the MG's, is credited with ''Sittin' on the Dock of the Bay'' (with Otis Redding), ''Knock on Wood'' (with Eddie Floyd) and ''In the Midnight Hour'' (with Wilson Pickett). Mr. Hayes and Mr. Porter wrote hits including ''When Something Is Wrong With My Baby'' and ''Soul Man,'' and Mr. Hayes won an Oscar for best original song for ''Theme From 'Shaft.''' The Sherman brothers' music was heard in children's movies including ''Mary Poppins'' and ''The Jungle Book,'' and their Oscar-winning songs include ''Chim Chim Cher-Ee,'' ''It's a Small World'' and ''Chitty Chitty Bang Bang.'' Mr. Withers's songs include ''Ain't No Sunshine,'' ''Lean on Me,'' ''Lovely Day'' and ''Just the Two of Us.'' An Honor Prince, a winner of two Grammy Awards this month, will add to his accolades when he receives the 2005 NAACP Vanguard Award, honoring those who have worked to increase understanding and awareness of racial and social issues, The Associated Press reported. The award will be presented during the 36th annual NAACP Image Awards on March 19 in Los Angeles. The event will be broadcast on March 25 on Fox television. Previous recipients of the award include the filmmakers Steven Spielberg and Stanley Kramer. Opera House Protest An Australian court yesterday rejected the appeals of two men who painted an antiwar slogan on the Sydney Opera House last March, The Associated Press reported. The men, David Burgess and Will Saunders, both 34, were sentenced last year to nine months of weekend jail time and ordered to pay $120,000 to clean the opera house, daubed with ''No War'' in huge red letters as Australian troops prepared to join the invasion of Iraq. The men based their appeal on self-defense, arguing that they acted to defend the lives of those who would die in Iraq. The New South Wales Court of Criminal Appeal said it would be ''outrageous'' to argue that an attacker could justify his actions ''by raising self-defense against an unrelated third party.''
docs.abstract: John Fogerty, Steve Cropper, Isaac Hayes, David Porter, Richard and Robert Sherman and Bill Withers will be inducted into Songwriters Hall of Fame on June 9 in New York; photo (S)

docs.snippet: For Santa Barbara County, removed from far more celebrated wine regions like the Napa Valley, the "Sideways" effect has been profound....
docs.lead_paragraph: AS the manager of Sanford Winery's rustic tasting room in the Santa Rita Hills just west of this crossroads town, Chris Burroughs usually greets visitors and pours wine. But since the film ''Sideways'' opened last fall, he has added a few duties: posing for photos with tourists, autographing their wine bottles and sharing his film-set memories. Mr. Burroughs's ticket to fame was just a few seconds on screen in ''Sideways,'' pouring wine for the actors Paul Giamatti and Thomas Haden Church, who play Miles and Jack, two old college friends off on a week of wine-tasting and carousing in Santa Barbara County. The film corralled rave reviews and five Oscar nominations, as well as an audience that seems entranced by the wines that Miles and Jack consumed and the places they went, if not by their excesses.
docs.abstract: Movie Sideways has had profound effect on Santa Barbara County and has transformed it into current hot spot for wine tasting; county has distributed 40,000 copies of Sideways map, detailing wineries and other sites that appear in film; photos (M)
